Award.AwardTitle: Pan-STARRS1: Operations; Public Data Release; Education and Outreach
Award.AbstractNarration:
AST-1238877

The Panoramic Survey Telescope & Rapid Response System (Pan-STARRS) is an innovative wide-field imaging facility developed at the University of Hawaii's Institute for Astronomy (IfA). The first telescope, Pan-STARRS1 or PS1, began full operations in May of 2010. Operating the PS1 System includes managing the observatory, the telescope and its camera, an image processing pipeline, a relational database, and servers for the reduced science products. The PS1 Surveys include five specific studies covering a wide range of astronomical problems: 1) a ~30,000 square degree survey of the entire sky north of declination -30 degrees, 2) a medium deep survey of some 70 square degrees in well-studied fields at high galactic latitude, 3) a solar system ecliptic plane survey optimized for the discovery of Near Earth Objects and Kuiper Belt Objects, 4) a stellar transit survey towards the Galactic bulge, and 5) a deep survey of the Andromeda galaxy (M31) to detect microlensing events. The PS1 Surveys will extend the scientific impact of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) with better image quality, depth, and area coverage, and will open up time-domain astronomy to enable the discovery of transient and variable phenomena. In order to make the PS1 data public and accessible as soon as possible and thus fully to exploit their scientific potential, the Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI) will create and support an archive of the PS1 data products that can serve the entire astronomical community.

This award supports three primary activities for the PS1 project: 1) finish the last four months of PS1 operations and complete the survey; 2) re-reduce the entire PS1 data set with a final astrometric reference catalog and the best ("uber") photometric calibration; and 3) enable a PS1 archive at STScI capable of serving the calibrated image data as well as a database of all detections and ~30 billion astronomical objects. The impact of making the PS1 data products available to the astronomical and outreach communities cannot be overstated. The photometric data alone will provide a high quality standard reference within the field of view of any astronomical imaging program on any telescope observing within the PS1 survey region. The impact of SDSS has been enormous: PS1 can confidently be expected to be even more significant, due to its better spatial resolution and depth, wider and deeper components, and access to the time domain.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Panoramic Survey Telescope and Rapid Response System (Pan-STARRS) is an innovative wide-field imaging facility developed at the University of Hawaii’s Institute for Astronomy (IfA) and located at Haleakala Observatories, Maui, Hawaii.  The Pan-STARRS Telescopes have a 1.8 meter aperture at f/4.4 using a Ritchey-Chretien design with a 3.2 degree diameter field of view, and the worlds largest digital camera, the 1.4 Gigapixel Camera. 

The Pan-STARRS1 Surveys were carried out over a four year period from May 2010 to April 2014 by the  PS1 Science Consortium. During that time nearly 400,000 images were taken, covering 3/4ths of the sky repeatedly, with each region having 60 to 100 exposures. This is the first large digital time domain survey of the sky. The images were analyzed and calibrated, providing the most accurate photometry (with systematic errors less than one half of one percent) of stars and galaxies across the sky. Over 8 billion objects were discovered and cataloged, with over 35 billion dectections. For most objects, dozens of attributes were measured and cataloged. The entire data set is available on line in the largest single release of astronomical data in history.

To make this release possible and to fully exploit the scientific potential of the Pan-STARRS1 Surveys, the PS1SC committed to make all the data public and accessible, and with the support of the National Science Foundation, partnered with the  Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI) in Baltimore Maryland, to house the Pan-STARRS archive and to make it available online from the Mukulski Archive for Space Telescopes (MAST). 

The Pan-STARRS Data Archive includes images and catalogs from several defined surveys, including the 3PI Steradian Survey which covers 3/4 of the sky and includes 60 to 100 exposures at every point.  In addition, there were nightly observations of ten smaller fields distributed across the sky (the "Medium Deep Survey", which is not part of DR1). The PS1 archive includes a  simple image search form for retrieving image cutouts and full images and a catalog search form to search the catalogs for objects near a sky position. A CasJobs SQL interface allows expert users to craft more sophisticated queries.

The archive includes nearly 2 Petabytes of images, and 150 Terabytes of catalog data in the form of a heirarchical database. Scientists from around the world are already downloading images and catalogs from the archive, and publishing papers. 

The Pan-STARRS Survey data products - images and catalog database - are fundamental astronomical resources. They contain a census of the solar system, the galaxy, and the universe as it was in 2010-2014. The publications from the PS1 enabled by the NSF include papers on Near Earth Asteroids, comets, trans-neptunian objects, ultra cool dwarfs and the "lonely planet", the three dimensional distribution of dust in the Milky Way, stellar streams from the merger history of the Milky Way, new campanion dwarf galaxies to the Milky Way, eclipsing binaries in the Andromeda Galaxy, new classes of explosive transients like superluminous supernovae and underluminous supernova, and a cosmological sample of SnIa. PS1 found over 100 high redshift from the first gigayear of the life of the universe. Many more unexpected discoveries will come from the public release of the Pan-STARRS1 Surveys, and new papers by the community are rapidly appearing, as evidenced by the citations of the Pan-STARRS1 Surveys paper. 

The Pan-STARRS1 Surveys have thus transformed several areas of astronomy and pushed the frontiers of astronomy outward, their public release and the rapid online availability will continue to transform both ground and space based astronomy as a reference source and as a enormous data set that has barely been explored. As the best available optical reference catalog, this work has broader impacts beyond the research described but will serve directly to provide a photometric and deep astrometric catalog of 3/4 of the sky. It will remain unmatched in the northern hemisphere. Other activities, such as the training of a new generation of astronomers in Big Data and in time domain astronomy, both undergraduate students, graduate students, and post-doctoral fellows, and our activities supporting the Professonal Development Program of the Institute of Scientist and Engineers Education have a direct impact on STEM education and training.

And it should be mentioned that at the most basic level, all Pan-STARRS data is taken on the NEO cadence to identify potentially hazardous asteroids, and this provides a unambigous level of hazard mitgation for society as a whole.
